items: Up to 5 tumor sites, maximum of 2 per organ.
Bi-dimensional measurements; calculate sum of longest diameters (SLD).
Choose target lesions easy to measure; identify non-target lesions (e.g., ascites/pleural fluid) to follow qualitatively.
Tumors in lung, liver, solid organs: measure long axis. Lymph nodes: measure short axis.
Target lesions: determine SLD; include lymph nodes with short axis > 15 mm.
Non-target lesions: <10 mm lesions, pleural fluid, ascites, etc.
Follow-up assesses disappearance, stability, or progression.

blocks.text: Absolute SLD increase should be >5 mm to call progression.

items: Tumors: choose large, well-defined lesions; longest diameter >10 mm.
Lymph nodes: short axis >15 mm can be targets.

Examples: liver mets (include hypervascular rim), bone mets only if soft tissue component; sclerotic lesions not suited for targets; mediastinal LN short axis >15 mm; lung metastasis >10 mm; inguinal LN short axis >15 mm.
Lymph nodes <10 mm normal; 10?"14 mm pathologic but not target; can be non-target. If target nodes shrink to normal, still include measurement.
Targeted therapy/Choi criteria: partial response if >15% decrease in tumor attenuation and >10% decrease in size.
PERCIST (PET/CT): tumor size %1 cm; response if >30% decrease in max SUV; progression if >30% increase.

Special staging: HCC response when arterial enhancement absent; GIST pseudoprogression?"use attenuation and PET response (imatinib). %15% attenuation decrease may indicate response even if size increases.
